nodes.text: A lexicon-based sentiment analysis system (SO-CAL) that uses hand-ranked multi-part-of-speech dictionaries plus linguistic handling of intensification, negation, irrealis, and weighting yields robust, domain-independent polarity classification and strength estimation
SO-CAL computes semantic orientation for texts by aggregating semantic orientation scores of words and phrases adjusted by contextual valence shifters and text-level weighting
SO-CAL uses manually created, hand-ranked dictionaries for adjectives, nouns, verbs, adverbs (scale −5 to +5), with multi-word expressions and part-of-speech distinctions

Intensification is modeled via a percentage-based modifier lexicon (amplifiers positive, downtoners negative) applied multiplicatively and recursively to capture scale and interaction with item strength

Negation is handled primarily by polarity shift (moving score toward opposite polarity by a fixed amount) with a conservative backward search for negators and optional polarity-flip treatment for intensifier interaction

SO-CAL implements irrealis blocking (ignore SO in scope of modals, conditionals, NPIs, questions, quotes) and exceptions for local definiteness, to avoid counting non-factive or hypothetical sentiment

Text-level features include negative-value weighting (boosting negative expressions), repetition weighting (nth occurrence scaled by 1/n), XML or positional weighting, and multiple cut-offs for fine-grained class labels

SO-CAL was evaluated on multiple corpora (Epinions 400 reviews development, unseen Epinions 400, Polarity movie reviews ~1900, Camera 2400) and shorter texts (MPQA sentences, MySpace comments, news/blog sentences, SemEval headlines)

SO-CAL achieved overall accuracies around 78.7% on mixed review corpora with full features enabled, outperforming simpler or single-part-of-speech lexicons and most automatic dictionaries in cross-domain tests

On shorter texts and other domains (MPQA, MySpace, news/blog sentences, headlines), SO-CAL attained comparable accuracy when non-empty (had SO-carrying words), e.g., 77–82% excluding texts with no matched lexicon words
Feature ablations show that negation handling, intensification, negative weighting and repetition weighting each improve accuracy; shifted negation generally outperformed simple switch negation
Mechanical Turk judgments of adjective and intensifier strength correlate substantially with SO-CAL manual rankings and pairwise comparisons, supporting the validity of the hand-ranked lexicons

Comparisons with other lexicons (Google PMI automatic dictionary, SentiWordNet versions, General Inquirer, Subjectivity lexicon, Maryland thesaurus-derived list) show SO-CAL's manual, POS-tagged, moderate-coverage dictionaries plus linguistic features produce higher cross-domain polarity accuracy

Limitations include: (a) too much automatic expansion can add noise and reduce performance, (b) negation and pragmatic phenomena are complex and neither shift nor flip fully capture all cases, (c) sentence-level/short-text empty cases arise from limited coverage

Conclusion: a linguistically informed, manually curated lexicon approach (SO-CAL) yields robust, portable sentiment polarity and strength detection across domains and text lengths, and can be improved further by discourse/topic weighting and targeted lexicon updates
